speaker: Neil

speaker: Neil

speaker: Neil
text: Have you heard the expression doomscrolling, Neil? It's when people spend a lot of time reading, or 'scrolling', a mobile phone or computer screen in order to read negative news stories - stories full of doom.

speaker: Neil
text: I hate to admit it, but I do sometimes doomscroll.

speaker: Neil
text: Sam

speaker: Neil
text: Well don't feel too bad, Neil, because you're not alone. Research from the University of California found that people all over the world doomscroll, regardless of culture. What's more, there may even be evolutionary reasons why we're attracted to bad news.

speaker: Neil
text: In this programme, we'll be investigating why we feel compelled to look at, and even seek out, bad news. And, as usual, we'll be learning some new vocabulary, as well.

speaker: Neil
text: Sam

speaker: Neil
text: But before that I have a question for you, Neil. Doomscrolling is a very modern idea which is only possible with the 24/7, non-stop cycle of news reporting. So, according to international news agency, Reuters, what has been the top global news story of 2023 so far? Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) The war in Ukraine?

speaker: Neil
text: b) Increasing prices and inflation?, or,

speaker: Neil
text: c) Prince Harry's autobiography?

speaker: Neil
text: I think the answer is an issue that's affecting everyone - inflation.

speaker: Neil
text: Sam

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Neil. I'll reveal the answer at the end of the programme. Now, it might be true that the non-stop news cycle makes doomscrolling possible, but that doesn't explain why we do it. Anthropologist Ella al-Shamahi thinks the answer may lie in human evolution. Here she outlines the problem for BBC Radio 4 programme, Why Do We Do That?

speaker: Neil
text: Ella al-Shamahi

speaker: Neil
text: We go searching out for bad news, looking for things that will make us feel ick inside. And so many of us do it. Is it a result of 24/7 doom on tap on our phones? Or, is it some kind of compulsion that comes from somewhere way, way back?

speaker: Neil
text: Sam

speaker: Neil
text: Reading bad news stories makes us feel ick - an informal American phrase which means feel sick, often because of something disgusting or disturbing. It's a feeling caused by the fact that, thanks to the internet, now we have the news on tap - easily available so that you can have as much of it as you want, whenever you want.

speaker: Neil
text: But Ella thinks that's not the whole story. There's another theory: way back in human history, when we lived in caves, it seemed everything could kill us, from wild animals to eating the wrong mushroom. Knowing what the dangers were, and how to avoid them, was vital to our survival, and from an evolutionary perspective, survival is everything. As a result, we humans naturally pay attention to the negative stuff, something Ella calls 'negativity bias'.

speaker: Neil
text: Sam

speaker: Neil
text: But while cavemen only knew what was happening in their local area, nowadays we know the bad news from all over the world. Here's Ella again, discussing this with her friend, TV presenter, Clara Amfo, for BBC Radio 4 programme, Why Do We Do That?

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Before it would be like, I don't know, I'm assuming you'd go to the neighbour's cave and they'd only know… the bad news from… that particular mountain. Whereas now, it's like, 'Let me tell you about the really bad information and situation that's going on in some island somewhere…'. It's just the good news doesn't make up for it…

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Clara Amfo

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: It really doesn't, and I think trauma's romanticised, really. 'What doesn't kill you makes you stronger', 'this is a test'. I think we're conditioned to believe that negative experiences shape us more than joyous ones.

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Neil

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Reading bad news from around the world can depress us, and Ella thinks that the little good news we do hear doesn't make up for the depressing news. To make up for something means to compensate for something bad with something good.

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Sam

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Good news is hard to find. In fact, Clara thinks society has romanticised bad, traumatic news. If you romanticise something, you talk about it in a way that makes it sound better than it really is. Connected to this is the saying, 'What doesn't kill you makes you stronger', meaning that by going through difficult experiences in life, people build up strength and resilience for the future.

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Neil

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Maybe it's best to stop doomscrolling altogether, but with so much bad news pouring into our mobile phones every day, it's not easy.

speaker: Ella al-Shamahi
text: Sam
